nodes.bodyText: Oops, this class should not have made it into the PR, fixing now.

Not the most readable block but as I understand it, we bail out of any final or entity with no default constructor.
If you can write a comment in that effect that will be a bit more readable.
Maybe even move that logic in a separate method
it's correct, as it mimicks the current semantics: we won't generate them for final classes or entities lacking a default ctor. Appropriate warnings / failures are generated later.
we only need subclasses to enlist their @Proxy, nothing else?
You can't enlist the subclasses themselves, as you can't inherit from multiple classes. From what I could see in the hibernate code this is all that is registered.
s/ret/preGeneratedProxies/g

@Sanne do you know if we need @MappedSuperclass in the list of classes we want to proxy? I guess no but it's unclear from ProxyFactoryHelper.extractProxyInterfaces for me. I guess getSubclassIterator() does not return mappedSuberclass. only real entities.
I don't see why we'd need it? The class is hopefully already extending its mappedSuperClass - or it's an user error.
yea, this would have no effect.
Please open an issue to Quarkus with a reproducer.
meaning add that to the message.

+1
Also could we include the details of the mismatch, if any. I think we're assuming that this will never actually happen, but if it does it would be super useful to know the class which was expected, if we had that class at all registered in any PreGeneratedProxies , and if we had it what's the interfaces mismatch.
I thought this could happen with Envars? This particular WARN would only happen if an entity was registered we don't know about.
Please open an issue to Quarkus with a reproducer.
meaning add that to the message.
(same content as above : we'll need to know the details of the mismatch)
maybe add a dog specific property (getFavoriteToy())

I know it's horrible, but given the context I think I'd prefer this method to be surrounded by a catch Runtime exception / log warning ?
That's to ensure that any unforeseen issue with those proxy generation will indeed get us the "falllback the current state" behaviour we discussed.
(Especially as the method intentionally throws RuntimeException on any CNFE)
p.s. as a fallback of course register an empty PreGeneratedProxies

Why does this get such special treatment? Any PR that normally included such a try/catch because the author was not sure if would work would get rejected. If there is an NPE or some other problem then IMHO this is no different to any other bug.
@Sanne maybe we should ask for broader review from the hibernate team if you are worried there are cases I have missed?

yes I would generally react like you say. but we decided to go very cautious here and promised that any problem this would fallback to the previous, slower behaviour gracefully.
As you prefer though, I don't consider it blocking.

@Sanne maybe we should ask for broader review from the hibernate team if you are worried there are cases I have missed?

because we either will get a timely answer but not entirely sure, or it will take much longer.
Against my better judgement I have added it.
Created #8447 to remove it in 1.5
thank you both!

Created #8447 to remove it in 1.5

why not in 1.4 ?

There's an important optimisation missing here: even if all proxies are generated upfront, we still initialize the Bytecode Provider!
The line final BytecodeProviderImpl bytecodeProvider = new BytecodeProviderImpl(); needs to become lazily evaulated if we aim to skip loading all those classes.
